The 'PT-76' is a Soviet amphibious light tank which was introduced in the early
1950s and soon became the standard reconnaissance tank of the Soviet Army and
the other Warsaw Pact armed forces. It was widely exported to other friendly
states, like India, Iraq, North Korea and North Vietnam. Overall, some 25
countries used the PT-76.

The tank's full name is Floating Tankâ76 (, Plavayushchiy Tank, or ). 76
stands for the caliber of the main armament: the 76.2 mm D-56T series
rifled tank gun.

The PT-76 is used in the reconnaissance and fire-support roles. Its chassis
served as the basis for a number of other vehicle designs, many of them
amphibious, including the BTR-50 armored personnel carrier, the ZSU-23-4 self-
propelled antiaircraft gun, the ASU-85 airborne self-propelled gun and the 2K12
Kub anti-aircraft missile launch vehicle.
